Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 05:25AM - edited Jul 8, 2011 05:31AM by Marybe   I have always had low body temp.  If I am at 98.6, I have a fever.  Normal for me is more like 96.8/97 range .  I also have low blood pressure and since both are "normal" for me sort of thought they went hand in hand. Whenever I am in the hospital and have any type of surgery, my BP really drops.  The lst time I had a neulasta shot my temp was at 101 and that was really high for me.  I can always tell when I am getting a fever because my eyes start to burn.  When other people are hot, I am usually comfortable and always need a sweater or some sort of jacket in the movie theater or at restaurants.  I have found that I am much more tolerant of heat than I am the cold so in the winter we really need to keep the heat cranked up for me to be comfortable. Even though sunbathing is not really recommended for anyone, I have always felt better with a tan and to this day, love sitting in the sun, soaking up the heat, even on really hot days.  When I had my Vit D levels checked simply because so many women on the threads were talking about them and how low levels seemed to go along with BC, mine was at 68 and I have never taken vitamins in my life (up until now and I am trying a few to ward off neuropathy) so I thought Ah ha, maybe all those years of basking in the sun paid off.      Since I have always been this way, I don't think it is any way related to my breast cancer.  Both my mother and father had low BP and my mother is gone, but I will ask my Dad about his body temp to see if I inherited that also.  I just saw this thread and guess I should go back and read the whole thing to find out if this is something I should worry about.  But at this stage of the game, I most likely won't.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 01:06PM Marybe wrote:       Stable IS a big deal. It's under control and not growing.  The hormonal treatments my oncologist had me on kept me stable for almost 10 years.  When I first started treatment there was almost a 50 % shrinkage in the lung tumors and from then on it was stable every time with the bone mets as well as the liver and lung until they saw some new bone mets in my sacrum and I had to have radiaton then and also moved from the hormonal to oral chemo which did not work because then with my next CAT scan there was a change in my liver..that was a huge blow because I had gotten so used to nothing changing.......BUT the good news is that the chemo he then changed me to, Avastin and Abraxane has once again caused them to say Stable and I am really happy about that.  I also know that I am not going to beat this since Stage lV is as far as you can go, BUT I got that diagnosis 11 years ago and I have been living a very normal life and have been able to work during that time frame. I was single up up until Dec 07, but did a lot of dating up until then and found out boobs really don't mean all that much to guys.   It is only lately that I am having side effects and that is from the chemo and I may have to go on SS disability, but at least I am still lving and able to do things and can truly say I do enjoy my life.  I think I appreciate life a lot more since my cancer diagnosis.Because I do act so "normal" and look so healthy (only lost my hair for the lst time a few months ago) most people don't recognize the seriousness of my cancer and they do say stupid things, but they mean well.  I said this is a post a long time ago and it is so true, but most people have just never thought of it.....We are all terminal, each and every person on the face of the earth.  Everyone is going to die one day, be it from cancer, diabetes, a heart attack or just old age.....we are all going to die.  What we need to concentrate on now is living each day to its fullest and make the most out of the life we have.  I totally know what you mean Lynn, about people callling.  When I am doing fine and the scans come back with no changes time after time, my friends get wrapped up in their own little lives and family as we all do, and I hear nothing from them.  When I get a bad report, they call up and want to know if they can run errands for me, help me clean, just want to get together to hang out....they mean well but it pisses me off because even though I know these are my friends, they only make these offers when they think I am going to die.  Now after this diagnosis with changes for the worse in my liver and starting on chemo, I heard from people I had not heard from in years because it is true bad news does travel fast.  Well, I told my husband I am going to have a list of people I do not want at my funeral.....like former classmates whom are only cordial to me at reunions because it is the thing to do but did not even speak to me in highschool.....I don't want those people coming to my funeral.  And actually I am not really going to have a "funeral" My mother thought they were morbid and so do I. ..I want to have more like a wake....have my true friends there, with lots of good food (which I hope to God I will be able to taste again before this is all over), drinks and my favorite songs playing....and I want them all to tell their favorite stories about things we did together, not sit around and be sad and mopey.  They always talk about fairweather friends and this kind of shows you who the real ones are.  The ones who have always been there for me are there for me now and I know they will be when the going gets rough....but even they say stupid things and it is because no one ever really knows what anything is like until they have been there.  Facing the reality of all this is a good thing, but it is always good to have hope.  The drugs I am being treated with today where not around when I got my lst diagnosis in 1990 so one never knows what might happen in the next 20.  I think it is wonderful to get so many opinions and information from all of you ladies.  My father isn't in denial about me as much as he is his brother....he always says my brother is just fine when I remind him he has alzheimers and takes a medication for it so my father sould not be talking to him about drinking martinis. since Uncle BIll's kids would have a fit if they heard my dad doing that...but when I told him my cancer was active again and that I was starting chemo, he says Well, you have put up a good fight.  I said Good grief, don't talk about me like I am dead Daddy....I am not giving up yet.  I mean it just really sort of threw me since my father is always the one saying how great I am doing and how he wants me to outlive him (as all parents want for their children.)  So even the best of them say something stupid, but I try not to hold it against any of them because they truly don't know what it is like.  Obviously upping the steriods has me back to the point where I am not sleeping....I need to get up for work in 4 hours so think I will go give sleep a try.  Hope tomorrow is a good day for all of us.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 01:25AM Marybe wrote:    Lynn, The tumor markers CA 27/29 aren't an accurate way of checking, but they do give some indication as to what is going on.  My onco told me that is why they do so many tests and do not rely on just one, but a combination of results.....I guess they get the most accurate picture from scans where they can actually see something.  BUT, I asked them to run the CA 27/29 when I had treatment on Wed. and today (yesterday actually since I am up in the middle of the night and it's now Sat.) the nurse called and told me they are at 87....that is down from 205 where they were a few months ago.  So accurate or not, that gives me cause to think this treatment is doing something good.  I have 6 more abraxane treatments and then have scans again....last time there was a slight decrease in the lesion on the left lobe of my liver (or maybe it was right, now I forget) so I am hoping maybe it will be even smaller.  The fact you got rid of one spot on your liver is great!  The main bad side effect I am having now is my finger nails, but if this treatment is actually doing something positive, I guess it is all worth it.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2010 03:08AM Marybe wrote:    Listen to DarleneDenise since she actually had brain mets also and is still here.  If I were you, I would ask to see my oncologist again and would take the letter with me and go over it and possibly take someone with you.  I have found over the years that I don't always (well most of the time actually) remember what my doctor tells me when I am there and it never fails that I forget to ask him something I wanted to know.  When I went for my initial consult with my onco (12 yrs ago) one of my more organized friends went with me and  took notes and even asked questions.  When I went to MDAnderson this past fall, my two best friends went with me and one took notes the entire time and it really helped because later I could go back and look at them and look things up and ask questions on this board.  This past week I had an appt with my onco here to discuss why he and the onco at MDA are so different in the way they think I should be treated...I made a list of questions beforehand and asked them and wrote down what he said.  I think sometimes when we are face to face with the doctor we don't always retain all they said and maybe a lot of times they don't say it...as may be the case with your doctor and he felt it easier to put words on paper.  But I would followup on it so you don't have to be worrying and wondering how much time you have left.  My onco will never give me a time frame because as he puts it, it is difficult to say and I like you am in remarkably good shape for all I have going on.  He told me that all of the other Stage lV patients who started treatment with him the same time I did (98) are long gone so I consider myself extremely blesses.   Definitely find out what treatment options there are for you.  Some women pooh-pooh positive thinking, but I feel there is a lot to be said for it.  I go according to how I feel....right now my tumors are larger than they were several months ago and I am sort of in limbo since we do not know if what I am trying now is working or not, BUT I feel really good...better than I have for a long time so I feel that has to count for something.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 02:57AM Marybe wrote: Robin,  There is still a possibility those other chemos may work so there is still hope.  I am having good results with Navelbine and know of others who are having the same with gemzar. It is wrong of me to say I know how you are feeling because we all react differently,  but I do know how down I feel when I get news that is not the best and feel like the walls are closing in and "this is it".  I will never forget when my lst scans were done( after I had passed the magic 5 yr mark)  and I found out I was Stage lV and I was consulting with my BS to see what he thought since I did not plan on staying with the onco I had been with in the beginning and he said Untreated, I would say, you've got about a year.  Of course I planned on getting some sort of treatment, but all I heard was about 1 year and I was thinking I will never get the basement cleaned. Silly, but that is what I was thinking.  Then I went to the library and read about stage lV and did not feel much better since it said about 5 years was the norm.  So here it is 12 years later and I am still here and so are you....and you have been one of my inspirations.  So investigate those possibilities.  I do believe in the power of prayer and you sure do  have a lot of those coming your way from the ladies on here.  Marybe

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 05:52AM Marybe wrote:      I am still doing faslodex in addition to my abraxane and avastin (t's those last two that are causing me all the side effects)..  I asked my onco why we are still doing faslodex, if the fact it did progress and there is now activity in my liver didn't mean it wasn't working and he said well, one might think that, but it does cut off my estrogen supply and since that is how my cancer is fed, he at least wants to cover that base and not allow the estrogen to cause more problems than I already have by not trying to block it.  I don't think I have any SE's from the faslodex....maybe hot flashes, but they are few and far between.  I tend to overlook side effects unless they are major ones......today when I was having my treatment I asked to look at my chart since I am going to be part of an internet interview and thought I should refresh my memory on my treatments.  I forgot about all the arthritis and pain meds I was on for bone pain for awhile....also thought I was on the tamoxifen ( remembered the hot flashes with it and the weight gain, but had forgotten the bad leg cramps)  for longer than I was and didn't realize that I have been on faslodex since 2004.  You are oh so right when you say what works for one of us, does not mean it will work for another.  Today I told them I thought I was coming down with something since I have been sneezing constantly and my nose is running (not my normal avastin congestion) and that I felt achy and my eyes were burning....the nurse hooking me up today and said well, you may have picked up something since your white count was low last time....it's better today.  My white count and my GR2 were low last time.....so I asked her how come nobody told me this last time and if it was low why didn't they give me one of those shots to bring it up and she said she didn't know, just that this time it's better and she showed me the two lab reports.  I find this to be upsetting and guess I need to learn more about what the codes mean and always look and question them, but when they hand me a paper and say everything looks good, I take them for their word since they are the ones who know those things.  Being extremely busy and understaffed does not justify this in my book.  Saint, how are you doing without the treatments?  Are you having any scans done to see if it's staying the same or progressing?  I was thinking today when the nurse was telling me what was going to happen to my fingernails and I was limping in there because my toes and feet are in such bad shape, that if he gives me a great report after we have the scans repeated when I have finished #24, that I will weigh the pros and cons about staying on this "longterm" as he calls it.  I do know that my cancer is slow growing, or so it used to be, and if I could get along just feeling good and not having to deal with chemo side effects, I might ask to stop after 24.  You are a very brave woman and also I think a wise one and I am taking your advice to heart on the SS issue. I normally have a Wed.AM appt, but they moved it to this afternoon late and I went after work.  I was so tired when I went in there all I wanted to do was get called back to the treatment room so I could take a nap under a nice warm blanket.  Now I have had my steroid premed mix and will probably be up most of the night......its a much lower dosage, but when it was really low I asked them to up it again, because I found being hyped up and having energy preferable to falling asleep the minute I sat down. When I started with the onco I see now, 11 yrs ago, I told him how important it was that I could maintain a "normal life", wanted to continue working, not feel like crap, be able to travel and enjoy doing things and that is why we did not jump into chemo as my original onco wanted to do.   I hope you have a good appt tomorrow, Diane..and will be thinking about you.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 12:54PM Marybe wrote:     I think it is good to have a positive outlook, but no one unless they are MaryPoppins or PolyAnna can have a positive outlook all the time.  We all have our down days and that is normal.  I have been living with Stage lV cancer for so many years that I have become comfortable,,,,well, I guess comfortable is a poor choice of words, but I am used to it andhave been extremely lucky in that it has not taken over my life.  However, whenver I get a new metastasis or a bad report, it knocks me for a loop and I start thinking about what will eventually be and get a little scared.  I have always said I am not afraid of dying, but do get scared and depressed when I think of how I could possibly die.  I do not want to be hooked to an IV in a room with drawn shades and people hovering around me like in a bad movie.  I remember my mother's last month when she was hooked up to a respirator ( she did have a living will and did not want life support, but everything went haywire and she agreed to the machine which was to be temporary and everything went downhill from there).  People who have not had cancer or a terminal illness looking them in the face, do not know what it is like to deal with and am I am sure it makes them uncomfortable talking about it since they do not know what to say.  Most of my good friends and I do not talk about my cancer all that much....they will ask how my treatment went or how I am feeling, but they don't say dumb things like Oh, you are going to be just fine, ....or you are going to beat this.....because they know that is not true. My husband on the other hand just doesn't talk about it I was yelling at him last night when he told me something a woman said in the treatment room yesterday afternoon and he said they couldn't have told her that and blah blah and I screamed at him, "What do you think she is doing?  Lying?  I am sure they did tell her that and you have no right to say they didn't because YOU do not know what it is like to live with cancer and do NOT know what you are talking about."  On that note, he retreated to his room with the bigscreen tv in the basement where he likes to watch the news all day long and complain about the world to the dogs because they listen to him and don't comment.  I am always telling him that unless he plans on doing something about it, just to quit his complaining. . Anyway, enough of home biliss tales.  Let me know how you do with the Avastin.I know a lot of people who are on it.   I get it twice a month.  For some reason was not blowing as much slimy blood and scabs the past few days and almost ( note I say almost) missed it and wondered if something was wrong.  I have started using Flonase and think it actually helps with the congestion. My eyes are really running today and I am still fighting the runny nose, but the aches now seem to be gone.....I think this is a cold or something I picked up and not a SE.      Well, Good night ladies.  I already had a nice little snooze as I went to bed at about 10:00 and just got up awhile ago to go to the bathroom and ended up in here at the computer.  Think I will go back to bed now.  I agree, it is wonderful to have someone to vent to, someone who knows, yet someone who does not necessarily have to agree with all we think since we are all different, have different responses and opinions, BUT at the same time we are all in the same boat.  Sometimes our boat may spring a leak, but hopefully it will stay afloat or  has lifeboats enough for all of us.

size.  I asked him about this and he said well, since I am ER+ and that seems to have been what has been feeding my tumors he hesitates to stop it altogether (keeping the estrogen at bay).  I wear a sleve when I garden or do anything with my arm, stripping wallpaper, painting, etc, that might aggravate it.  I was measured and had this made by a company called Jobst.  They also made a glove to go with it, but I normally do not use the glove....I can tell where the swelling is when I do have it....my watch band always cuts it off so wearing something tight does control it.....have never had fullblown lymphadema.  I only showed a slight decrease in the one tumor in the Rt lobe I think it was after 12 treatments.....he now wants to do 12 more which will make 24 and we will repeat the scans.  This is abraxane I am on so don't know if it works like your drug or not.  I also get avastin 2/mo.  As of now I am just doing what my onco recommends since he has kept me going 11 yrs at Stage lV......if there is no more improvement at 24 we are going to have a big discussion.  The side effects are not so bad I cannot live with them for now, but if the neuropathy gets worse and my fingernails really do fall off as they look like they will do, that means I will be going on SS disability and I really do like working.  Odd thing is I am actually feeling less numbness this week and also my nails seem to just be staying where they are......so of course I am thinking hmmm, has it stopped working or is my body just adjusting.  It is always a big wait /weigh came and not one we can really guess at just have to hope we are doing the right thing.  Oops reread your post and answered my own question....you are Not on faslodex as of now.  Do they do tumor markers on you.....how do those look.....they aren't always accurate, but might give you some clue as to what the cancer is doing.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 08:33AM - edited Mar 11, 2012 08:36AM by Marybe   Susan is correct, you should get to deduct a lot due to medical.   My husband pays for the ins so I don't get to add that in since we file separately, but if you do yours together you get to add in ins premiums, co-pays, what your out of pocket expenses were, medical supplies not covered by ins and it can add up to a LOT.     I hate income tax time, hate it, hate it.   Last year I had myself worked into a real dither over it, just could not make myself even look at the stuff and get it gathered up until the very last minute.....and I don't even do my own!!   All I have to do is get the material to my friend who does them for me.   This year I must be in a better place mentally because this morning I actually hauled the stuff out of the filing cabinet and took all the envelopes upstairs and have started making little piles on the big table up there.   Bad news is one of my W2's seems to be missing.   I am not going to panic yet since I still have a month and I know it is here somewhere, but as of today it is missing.  I think I can get another copy or my friend who does them says just to use my last paycheck stub for the year and I do have that.....at least I think I do.   Organized I am not.   But do check and see if you aren't able to get a big refund and also check into some sort of aid programs as Susan suggested.   PS   You can even add the cost of gas for to and from Dr's appts....which I have never bothered to figure out, but I know it's allowed.

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 04:10AM Marybe wrote:   Getting cancer in other parts of her body as another type of cancer are not as likely as getting metastasized breast cancer in other parts of her body or other breast.  I believe if it was lobular there is a good chance it will go to the other breast.(mine was not lobular so I am just saying what I think, don't know and mine did not occur in the other breast)   Or if she gets mets, they can go anywhere else, example, bone or organs, but it will still be called breast cancer.  However, this does not have to happen and it is not something you should sit around worrying about.  Did she have any chemo, did they test lymph nodes, is she ER+. Did they do chemo after the surgery?  There are a lot of factors to take into consideration and I would think that her oncologist would have done all that can be done in the way of preventing a recurrence that he feels is needed.  I was very happy when I was told I did not need to do anything other than have a mastectomy, BUT this was back in 1990 and they were still testing tamoxifen and also did not know all they know now and saddly mine did come back and was not diagnosed until 8 yrs later.   However as I said this DOES NOT have to happen to your wife, but I would be asking some questions if I was her.....is she still going for bloodwork and check ups?  Do they plan on doing scans every year,or 2 yrs.  I doubt that they just sent her on her merry way and said this chapter of your life is over.  I wish it worked like that, but it doesn't.  Prevention is the key.  I am not saying worry and think of nothing else, but I am saying you have to stay on top of it.  I hope all goes well for her and you are a good husband to be worried about her.  Have a wonderful holiday and be grateful you are together and that she is cancerfree.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 04:50AM Marybe wrote: Well, I will be honest with you, I really do not know what to think or do.  So many women are saying Go somewhere else, get a new oncologist.  I would be the lst to agree that lately it does not seem like I am getting very good care and I myself feel his attitude is rather blase' (I mean it is my life we are talking about here) like tut, tut, no big deal, we need to see what is going on with scans.  I hate the fact that my entire life hinges on scan results, but that seems to be the way it is.  I am losing faith in the man and know things have changed drastically at the entire office in the past few months and only found out yesterday from one of the nurses that one of the hospitals bought them out.  I don't know if that is the reason for all the tension there, the fact that so many nurses are no longer there and the fact the patients are waiting what seems like forever in the treatment room, but something has definitely changed.  And I am not happy about it, BUT at the same time, this is the oncologist whom I feel is responsible for me being here today.  I want to a really bad one  before who didn't listen to my complaints and didn't do tests when I had pain.....and I went from Stage  1 (actually they told me the tumor was so small, it wasn't even a stage yet) to Stage lV while under her care due to what I consider neglect.  She wanted to start me on heavy duty chemo because she said we didn't have a lot of time and it was serious....Serious all of a sudden after me saying something was going on for over two years!!  Well, I asked my surgeon what to do since I did trust him and told him I felt I needed a new oncologist and he sent me to Dr.Cody.  Dr.Cody agreed it was serious, but not actually life threatening YET and he wanted to try me on  hormonal therapy since up until then I had no actual treatment other than a mastectomy, but I was ER+PR+ and he felt I would respond favorably.  And I did.....very favorably and I was able to get by with hormonal treatments and aredia (later zometa) for my bones for many many years before ever going to chemo.  I will always be grateful to him for those years because even though many women have SEs with tamoxifen, aromasin, faslodex and the others, they were very tolerable for me and did not interfere with my quality of life at all.  The one chemo I was on I found to be awful....that was the abraxane/avastin combo....I did 22 weeks of it and quit because the SEs with it were not only affecting my ability to work, it was affecting my quality of life.  That was when I went to MDA in Houston.  I tried going back on hormonal which the onco there suggested, but those failed and since then have been doing the suggestions for chemo that my local onco here has had....navelbine, gemzar and this last one halaven.  It is not official on the halaven, but given the rise in my CA27/29 I would think it is a good guess that is in not working.  I will know a lot more after my scans which are today and Monday.  And then what?  I just do not know.  I am going to write the onco at MDA who has been wonderful about staying in touch with me via email and get his opinion.   Several people have suggested that I have my tumor (s?...I don't know) retested to see if my status has changed....if I am still ER+PR+, Her2-....I guess the cancer can mutate and the receptors change and if they have maybe this is why I am not responding to the chemos I have been on.  I just don't know.  I have several friends who are currently under the care of oncologists here and I cannot say they are getting much better results....oh maybe their cancer is under control, but they are at a much earlier stage of the game than I am....newbies so to speak and have only been under treatment for a year to 1 1/2years.....I have been doing this for 21 years now, although I really only count myself as having been in treatment the past 13 when I switched oncos.  They have the long waits, they have the complaints about oncos not listening and the nurses not getting them in and out, plus I have met two of these oncos and was not impressed.   I like my guy, just am losing faith.  I am going to write to the onco at MDA and see what his thoughts are.  Since I am seeing all of this as signs that it really is time to quit working, I am willing to go to TX and stay for weeks if they want to run all my tests there.  I am also willing to go to Slone Kettering.  However, I just really don't what I should be doing at this point.  However, I do want you all to know that I very much appreciate all your prayers, thoughts and concern.   I would be lost without my BCO support.

Posts.Title: How to handle the Doctor Situation gonnabstrong dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 07:11PM - edited Aug 27, 2009 07:14PM by Marybe    I like to know what is in store so read everything I can find about the drugs they put me on, but I was very fortunate in that tamoxifen, aromasin, zometa, cytoxin, methotrexate ( last two were oral form)  and I forget what all I took did not give me SEs....or if they did they were so minor I forgot about them and did not at the time attribute them to the meds I was on.....example: did have some bone aches and pain, but thought it was arthritis and arthritis meds did take care of the problem.  I did have hot flashes and went into menopause with tamoxifen but figured that was on the horizon anyway and I just went through it faster than most.  Effexor did help me with the hot flashes. With avastin I experienced the congestion and nose bleeds and was constantly blowing disgusting things out of my nose, but it was something I could live with.  Then came the abraxane.  I had every single side effect on the list plus my taste buds totally stopped functioning and I do not recall that being mentioned.  I met a woman in the treatment room and saw her fingernails and she told me she had been on abraxane.....I asked one of the onco nurses if that was going to happen to me and she said Oh no.  That woman has been on so many treatments it could have been a combination of any of them, but abraxane doesn't do that.  NOT!  But maybe part of what she told me was true, it actually did worse things to my nails....not only did they look like the nails you see with fungus, they oozed this horrible smelly lymphlike fluid before the nail got loose.....finally after complaining about this smell for a month, the PA did a culture and told me the nails were infected and put me on several different antibiotics, none of which really worked.  I had a hard time keeping the dogs and the cat away from my nails as they thought it was rotten meat or something....that is how they smelled.  My eyes got to the point where they were tearing so much it was like looking through a windshield with defective wipers.....everytime I mentioned my weepy eyes, I would just get oh that's a SE.  I learned from another patient if I had had tubes put in my tear ducts right when this started I could have prevented the ducts from clogging.  Since quitting treatment I did have the surgery done on my eyes, but it's been a month now and they are still tearing so I don't know if they will go back to normal or not.  The final straw for me was the neuropathy...I could handle numb toes, I could handle it moving up the foot a little, but then my entire foot got numb and I started tripping and even fell a few times....that last week it started developing in my hands and my thumb went numb and still is...that was when I knew it was time to quit.  I got premeds because I was actually alergic to the avastin....got a red rash the very first time on my neck and chest.  I told them I didn't want benedryl because I had to go to work so my combo was aloxi, decamethazone, and tagament (excuse the spelling on those and I may not even be right with the deca one, but know it was a steroid)  I would feel great after my treatment, raring to go, but on Friday late afternoon I was ready to crash and when I would go to bed would sleep until the next afternoon....this was after a Wed. treatment. Sometimes I would have a rip roarin case of diarrhea, but other times I would not go for five days. The edema was horrible, but I think that is finally under control with water pills and support stockings.  Since I had not had bad SEs with anything before I went into this thinking it probably would not happen to me, but also dreading it because I had said all along I did not want to do chemo.  And now I know why.  Since I quit my treatments ( I did 22, not the 24 as planned) my taste is back, I am not only growing hair, but the eyebrows and eyelashes are also starting to come it, my nails are still eventually going to come off, but they are so much better and the smell stopped within a week of stopping chemo.  My eyes are still weeping, but maybe I just haven't given the surgery enough time and will see the opthalmic surgeon again in a week.  The neuropathy is still unchanged, but at least it has not gotten any worse.  I really did not have bad SEs until after almost 3 months of treatment and then every week they got a little worse.  Now I am faced with what to do next.  We are taking "a break" and I am loving it, but will say I am more tired now than I was during the treatments and when it hits it is almost like narcolepsy.  I never required a lot of sleep so this is all new to me and not something I like. Also my skin is horrible....on my arms it looks like chicken skin and it just sort of hangs there.....I am no spring chicken, but this looks like an 80 yr old woould have. I used to look younger than my years and did not have many wrinkles at all, now I think I look like I have aged at least 6 yrs in 6 months.  I have been investigating other treatment options, but my onco keeps saying But the treatment was working.  Yes it did shrink the tumors in the liver, but I question at what cost if this neuropathy stays with me.  He wants to do a drug in the same family since the abraxane was working as he puts it.  That means taxol or taxotere and the SEs listed for those are almost exactly the same as Abraxane.  No longer do I read these things and think Oh it won't happen to me .  I was not scared when I got my first chemo treatment....really did not want to do it, but felt I had no options since the AIs and oral chemo were no longer working for me.  If I do it again, I will be scared because I know what could happen.  I have been at this a long time, but nothing about this disease is predictable.    Oddly enough I like my port.....since they can only use my non mastectomy arm and I have veins that are small and roll, I shudder when a nurse(this only happens in the hospital since at my onco office they always use my port)  insists on using my arm because very seldom am I ever lucky enough to get one who can hit a vein the first try and sometimes not even on the 2nd or 3rd. Mine is above my left breast  near the center and very much resembles a doorbell.  It is there because they tried thee veins to hook it up with and failed so it goes into my jugular and at first you could see it going up my neck.  What do I wish they would have told me about chemo before I started it?.....Maybe not just that it could save my life, but it would make me feel like I was dying in the process.  I know I should be greatful to be here, but I have nothing good to say about the way I responded to chemo, even if my onco is still saying But it was working.
Posts.Title: What we wish we had known about chemo before we started! ddlatt kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: Marybe wrote:        I have to start a new treatment since the halaven did not work for me as my onco had hoped.  My tumor markers are up to 3,173 (probably higher, but that was what they were when we did a CA 27.29 a few weeks ago) and the tumors in my liver have increased in size....the largest one is now 7.2X 6.6.  He said he thought Ixempra and I asked about Xeloda since the onco I saw at MDA recommended it some time ago and when I told him the latest and had my reports and scans sent to him,he again said he had no reason to think Xeloda would not work for me.  So then my onco thinks for a moment and tells me that there is a regime with Ixempra and xeloda....2tabs of xeloda in the morning and two at night for two weeks, then one week off and the Ixempra via IV every 21 days.  So I asked the onco at MDA what he thought of this and he said it might add to the effectiveness if it was a last ditch effort, but he thought it would be better to do Xeloda lst and then move to Ixempra if it didn't work....reason being he felt I would have increased problems with neuropathy and he put in parentheses (you don't need any more of that).  I have not yet talked to my local onco, but am sure he will not go for this since he does not like suggestions from other people.  Also I had read that you should not be on warfarin (coumadin) while on Xeloda.....the onco at MDA said that is correct and I should switch to fragmen or lovenox.....I don't mind giving myself shots in the stomach, but can't imagine the cost of that....yet I know there is at least one woman and the chemo thread who does that.  Also there is another on coumadin who has no problems with the Xeloda causing problems with her INR.  My INR is out of whack most of the time anyway it seems.  I asked my onco about this being a problem with xeloda and he said we would just check it weekly.  I have had many blood clots plus a PE so there is no hope of me going off the stuff.  So I am interested in hearing what sort of results and SEs any of you had with either of these drugs and if any of you did them together?  Also if you do or did Xeloda, did you do the 14 days or 7 days on, 7 days off.  When I showed my onco the info on the 7/7 he said they were not getting a full dose and it would be less effective, but I think he was wrong on that one and once again just did not like me suggesting something other than the way he does it. He wants me to start next week and I was all set to do both, but then after what the other onco said, I am worried and would prefer doing them one at a time....unless someone has had phenomenal results by doing them as a combo.  I also get Xgeva once a month. Thanks for any experiences you have to share.     Marybe Marybe Be you own advocate and keep on your toes. I went from no stage (1990) to Stage lV while under an onco's supervision. Posts.Content: Marybe wrote:        I have to start a new treatment since the halaven did not work for me as my onco had hoped.  My tumor markers are up to 3,173 (probably higher, but that was what they were when we did a CA 27.29 a few weeks ago) and the tumors in my liver have increased in size....the largest one is now 7.2X 6.6.  He said he thought Ixempra and I asked about Xeloda since the onco I saw at MDA recommended it some time ago and when I told him the latest and had my reports and scans sent to him,he again said he had no reason to think Xeloda would not work for me.  So then my onco thinks for a moment and tells me that there is a regime with Ixempra and xeloda....2tabs of xeloda in the morning and two at night for two weeks, then one week off and the Ixempra via IV every 21 days.  So I asked the onco at MDA what he thought of this and he said it might add to the effectiveness if it was a last ditch effort, but he thought it would be better to do Xeloda lst and then move to Ixempra if it didn't work....reason being he felt I would have increased problems with neuropathy and he put in parentheses (you don't need any more of that).  I have not yet talked to my local onco, but am sure he will not go for this since he does not like suggestions from other people.  Also I had read that you should not be on warfarin (coumadin) while on Xeloda.....the onco at MDA said that is correct and I should switch to fragmen or lovenox.....I don't mind giving myself shots in the stomach, but can't imagine the cost of that....yet I know there is at least one woman and the chemo thread who does that.  Also there is another on coumadin who has no problems with the Xeloda causing problems with her INR.  My INR is out of whack most of the time anyway it seems.  I asked my onco about this being a problem with xeloda and he said we would just check it weekly.  I have had many blood clots plus a PE so there is no hope of me going off the stuff.  So I am interested in hearing what sort of results and SEs any of you had with either of these drugs and if any of you did them together?  Also if you do or did Xeloda, did you do the 14 days or 7 days on, 7 days off.  When I showed my onco the info on the 7/7 he said they were not getting a full dose and it would be less effective, but I think he was wrong on that one and once again just did not like me suggesting something other than the way he does it. He wants me to start next week and I was all set to do both, but then after what the other onco said, I am worried and would prefer doing them one at a time....unless someone has had phenomenal results by doing them as a combo.  I also get Xgeva once a month. Thanks for any experiences you have to share.     Marybe Marybe Be you own advocate and keep on your toes. I went from no stage (1990) to Stage lV while under an onco's supervision. Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 06:16AM - edited Jul 28, 2011 06:17AM by Marybe Oh wow.....I am just so confused and my onco is not very reception to opinions or suggestions at all.....not even from MDA and the lst time I was talking about going for 2nd opinions it was HE who said if I did I needed to go to somewhere like MDA or Slone that had a BC unit.  TooYoung....The evil Gemzar?.....I had no SEs with that one except for constipation.  I just think it is amazing how we all react so differently to these drugs.  When you come right down to it we are just a bunch of lab rats in human form.  I did not really have SEs from navelbine, gemzar or halaven except constipation...and some, but not total hair loss with halaven. Had some pretty weird muscle spasms with halaven. Also somewhere along the way developed acid reflux and was taking protonics, but had to move up to nexium....but I think that all started back with methotrexate/cytoxin.  I have also had neuropathy, but thank goodness it seems to go away....not totally, but is restricted to my toes.  I asked my onco is I could be chemo resistant and he said he didn't think there was such a think, but that some cancer cells are more resistant to one chemo that another.  This would be a lot easier decision for someone who doesn't go back and forth and question everything the way I do.  Thanks for your response....hope and pray you all do well.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 09:14PM Marybe wrote:    Thanks everyone for your input....I really think Xeloda is the way to go.  The onco at MDA told me to do the two weeks on,  one week off and if I find the SEs too bad to switch to one week on, one week off....he also told me that usually it gets worse toward the end of the cycle like day 12 or so and if my feet and hands are really bothering me to just skip days 13 & 14.  I took the Rx to Kroger pharmacy since they had the medication in stock....my little local one said they might lose money on it if I didn't use all they ordered since they have no other customers on it and I guess they have to order it in a certain quantity...can't get just 56 pills for me.  So now the pharmacy will be told by the ins co, that it has to be preauthorized and my onco's office will have to call the ins co and it will go back and forth, but I am sure they will iron it all out by Wed. They keep mentioning the cost, but I have no idea just how expensive it is.  Then I have my appt and hope I have the guts to tell the onco I only want to do Xeloda at lst and if it doesnt work or if it does, when it stops working (as we know they all eventually do) I will then do Ixempra...but who knows maybe he will be thinking of another one by then.  Also I plan on going back to TX in maybe Oct. 'Thanks for the PM, Judie....it made sense to me.   I hope your mother continues to do well, Mary.   I am totally pooped and tomorrow we start at 8 so I am going to bed.  Last week I was working as few hrs as possible since I was sure I was going to do SSDI,  this week I am working every day and thinking maybe I made a big mistake canceling my appt with SS, but first I need to get a treatment underway and then I can worry about the other.  Has anyone ever had an onco fire them?  I have been with this guy for 13 yrs now, but things have changed and he never really did exactly put off warmth, but lately he is just so blase' and I feel like I am irritating him when I ask questions.   I do think I should at least go talk to someone else, but am not planning on leaving him unless we just can't agree at all on treatment.....but then I started thinking, Hmmm, wonder if he might just tell me to hit the road and go find another onco.  I think that happened in a Seinfield episode, but dont know if it happens in real life.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 06:22AM Marybe wrote:   Yesterday went fine....better than fine....nothing short of a miracle in my opinion, really.  That blood test he did on me last week...the one I forgot about actually until the PA told me the results...the one that was to check to see if possibly my cancer had changed and I had become positive and able to do herceptin......well, she told me the numbers were elevated on the cell test we did and I asked what test?, did we do a cell search again? (which would have surprised me since the ins will no longer pay for that and they know it at the office)  Anyway, she told me it meant I could be treated with herceptin so she went to run it by the onco and then of course they had to get it OKed with the ins.  She said it was not real high and the ins might require a biopsy....I guess below 15 is normal, negative -?.....anyway, mine was 30.....But the ins did OK it!!!    So now I am going to get herceptin starting next week and am starting my Xeloda this morning!!!   He told me it was a long shot when he ordered the test, but it came back the way we wanted it to!!!! He said maybe four of the women out of 200 they had tested to see if they had changed came back positive and mine did!!   I am #5.  I always heard it was better not to be her2+, but at this point is means another option for me.....also I think they have come up with a few more other than herceptin. but can't swear to this....I was too shocked and happy to ask, was just smiling from ear to ear.  And she ran all this by the onco and he is fine with it.   No Ixempra for now for me.  And she said Oh he would never do that when I told her I was afraid he would just say Hit the road if Ididn't want to do his recommendations....so I was just building this big thing up in my head as I sometimes do....always think the worst that could happen.  As I told the PA when Iwas asking all about the INR and Xeloda and how often I could have it checked....I said I worry...people think I am doing so well with this and handle things so well and that I am so calm and collected, but I DO WORRY.   Thank you everyone, PJB, KLo, Judie, KsinghO, Sweetwater, Shan and all of you for all your love, support  and input. I am now triple positive in both tumor type and mental outlook!! Have a great day everyone!!    Marybe

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 04:39PM Marybe wrote:  Hi, I am the Marybe Anna spoke of.  I don't know how much I know about eyes, but I certainly have had a time with them and posted questions about them last summer.    I was on abraxane which is in the same family.  My eyes were watering so much that it actually interfered with my vision.....was like looking thru a blurry windshield that the wipers just weren't moving fast enough to clear.   I went to my opthamalogist and he tried to unplug the ducts which had closed over, but they would not stay open so he then sent me to a specialst and I actually had surgery.....had cannula (I think that is what they called the little tubes) put in both upper and lower ducts. Most likely the same thing TX 357 had put in. That was over two months ago and I am still using the post surgery drops and to tell you the truth do not know if things have improved or not other than the fact tears now run out the sides and just aren't overflowing the lid and gushing down my face.the way they were.  The surgeon tells me that these little tubes are to re-establish a new drain and once he takes the tubes out everything will go back to normal.  But he also added that if it doesn't work, not to worry, that he will fix me up.  This may seem like a petty complaint compared to neuropathy and other SEs (which I also have) but the tearing eyes really annoy me, make it difficult to see, and dry out my skin and don't ask me how, but somehow the tears manage to go up over my lids and it gets all crusty up there.  The latest thing is my eyes are stuck together in the AM.(like Lassie11 wrote about)  I do have eyelashes that have grown back, but dont' use mascara since it always did bother my eyes.  Only one eyeliner I have even goes on, but it is usually washed off by the end of the day.  The thing that upset me the most about this is that a woman I used to talk to during treatment told me IF you went to the opthamalogist early enough and did something to keep the ducts open, you were more likely not to have a long lasting problem.....BUT NO ONE TOLD ME THIS.  The pamphlet they gave me about SEs said may affect vision, but I didn't know it would be due to tearing.  I sympathize with each and every one of you who has this problem......it is more than annoying, it is a big PIA.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 07:38AM Marybe wrote: Tough question, about as difficult as doing chemo or not.  Speaking as someone who has been Stage lV for a long long time, I am all for getting as many opinions as possible and going for insurance coverage that will pay for it.  I actually got married just so I would have good insurance which I cannot say was the wisest choice in the world since I am POed at my husband most of the time, BUT I at least don't have to worry about selling the house in order to go for an out of state opinion.  Once we meet the deductible and out of pocket maximum everything is covered, but I still look at the treatment bills and it is absolutely amazing what chemo costs, not to mention MRIs or PET scans, of which I have only had one, but it was so much more than the CAT and bone scans I get which themselves are not cheap.  It would take no time at all to wipe out a nest-egg.  Not to be a pessimist or doubting Thomas, but Stage lll is not that far away from Stage lV so if you have an opportunity to get better coverage now, I myself would go for it.  On the brighter side of that,  Stage lV does not mean an immediate end.....I have been dealing with and treating it for almost 14 yrs now.....it is doable, but it costs lots and lots of money and without good insurance coverage would be impossible.  This is just MHO.    It's sad that we have to worry about this kind of crap, when we should be deciding whom to take off the Xmas card list or what to wear to a Christmas party this time of year.  I wish you the very best in making your decision.     Marybe

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2011 06:15AM Marybe wrote:    I don't know what to tell you.  My onco is always telling me the CA27.29 is not an accurate indication of what the cancer is doing, but we still do the test and whenever it goes up, usually the scans will show progression.  He may not want to admit it because he doesn't want me freaking out, but I am sure it is an accurate indicator for me.   The beginning of August when I started Xeloda, mine were.....are you ready for this?....3,306!!!   Am I worried, heck yes, but the really strange part of this is that even though they are sky high, and my scans show progression, the worst being in the liver, I still feel fine.  I am going to work, doing yard work, and carrying on as usual.  Supposedly a lot of things can affect them, stress, antibiotics, infections, but 3,306!!!....that is ridiculous.   If I ever get back to the 100s I will be throwing a big party to celebrate! I am not trying to make light of your situation, but would not be overly worried if they are 36 or 37.  Just ask they to run the test every so often to see if they are on the rise.  My onco was always more concerned with the cell search which told if any cancer cells were traveling around in the blood stream, (and fortunately that always came back zero), but now my insurance won't pay for that test....says it is not an accurate diagnostic tool for metastatic breast cancer.  Easy for them to say.   I hope all goes well for you and you can avoid further treatment or recurrences for many many more years.  Marybe

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 07:58PM Marybe wrote: Abraxane!! Oh no, my worst enemy!!  But I will have to admit it did work.  I had an appt with the cardiologist this AM and she commented on how she noticed my nails and wondered if it was from chemo!  And here I was thinking they were looking pretty normal....they are almost in my opinion.....just about 1/4 of my thumb still has to grow out...ends are yellow and thick and look like I have fugus there. They are not attached there toward the ends so I get stuff under them and always have to clean them out.  It has been since end of July 2009 that I had my last abraxane treatment...that was #22   The lst thing my nails did was discolor...looked like they were bruised, and the got very yellow...I could have passed for a two pac a day smoker. Then they sort of detatched from the nail bed and lifted up.  This would not have been so bad if they had not become infected and they ooozed when I pushed on them, pus came out and boy did it stink.  It smelled just like rotten meat....I had a difficult time keeping the dogs and cat away from my hands and feet.  They thought it was feeding time at the zoo.  I did not lose my fingernails, but cut them very short, one almost down to nothing, so they would not catch on things.  No antibiotics worked since the reason was chemo and they did not start to get better until after chemo.  Several of my toenails I was able to just pull off and my podiatrist removed my big toe nails....believe it or not my toes felt a lot better once they were gone. They would ooze and stain my socks.  I still do not have complete nails on my big toes and I can't say what is there looks like a toenail.....it it sort of an opague cracked mess and very brittle, and only covers about 1/2 the nailbed....sort of crumbles when I trim them.  I don't look at them much so they really do not bother me, however after what the cardiologist said today, I am wondering how many people will be looking at my toes and thinking I wonder if it's catching?  What really made me mad was I asked the nurses after seeing a woman in the treatment room with awful nails right before I started on the abraxane, Is that going to happen to me?and she looked me right in the eye and said" Oh no, that isn't going to happen with abraxane.  That woman has been on mutiple treatments so it is difficult to say what caused that."  I think eventually they are all going to get back to normal, but it is sure taking a long time for mine. the nails never did thin, they are hard as a rock.  Susan, Re neuropathy.....I had it something awful....my ankles were actually hanging over the sides of my shoes IF I could even get shoes on.....onco did not seem very concered, but the cardiologist gave me a Rx for triamterine (very low BP pill which I do not need because I do not and never did have high BP) HCTZ which really works...better than lasix.  I hated Abraxane and its SEs....tearing eyes were a huge issue also....you name it, I got it, BUT as I said it worked and actually no chemo has since I went off of it, but I am hoping this new one will   Sorry I did not have much good news to share with you.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 04:22AM Marybe wrote: Of course you aren't stupid.  As several have already told you, you have hope and it is a realistic hope.  I have been Stage lV since May 1998, that is over 12 years ago.  And I was in remission for many of those years when I was being treated with lst Tamoxifen and then Aromasin, moving onto Faslodex. When those stopped working, I moved on to chemo, but did one that was really hard on me so chose to quit (however it did shrink my tumors).  Now I am doing another chemo and this one isn't causing me any real problems at all with side effects and I am still working and doing my usual things.  My oncologist who is not a warm fuzzy type guy who sugarcoats things always tells me like it is and he said he has no reason to think he will not once again be able to put me back in remission.  I don't know what Stage you are, but if I can do this well for this long at Stage lV, there is no reason to believe you can't do even better.   The trick is finding what works for you.  You are not stupid at all, just wondering about what IF and what lies ahead as we all do.

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2011 01:13AM - edited Jun 10, 2011 01:14AM by Marybe I get those also, but did not know if it had anything to do with this drug or if I am just that out of shape ( I am)....I will make a move to do something and it will pull my back so I try to move around and get rid of that problem and then it will pull elsewhere.....but none of these things last for very long.  Except for my right shoulder and that has been in bad shape for over a week now, but has inproved due to icing it and just trying not to overtax it....I really think I did it stretching too far trying to reach something one day last week, but since they mentioned my humerus in the scan report of course I worry Uh, oh, wonder if it's the cancer.  This was my week off so all I had done was blood work and that came back fine....white count was at 19 which is of course from the neulasta elevating it.  Yaiy, when you spoke of trying not to react to these spasms when you were in public, I had this visual of Steve Martin in the Jerk when he was trying to show that he had rhythm.  The hair loss has really slowed down so that it is barely coming out now and I had it all trimmed shorter yesterday and it looks almost OK  IF you don't look too closely....under a bright light my pink scalp sort of shines through, but it beats wearing a wig or a bandanna and as long as my boss doesn't object and I don't feel totally self-conscious I am working without head apparel.  Had I not had lots of hair am sure it would be almost gone by now.  So other than hair loss and constipation, I am feel "normal".   I have not noticed any more neuropathy than I already had and am taking the vitamins and supplements that were recommended to prevent it faithfully.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2012 10:52AM Marybe wrote: Menan,   No SEs does not mean it isn't working or so my onco tells me, but that has been the case with me. Remember, with all chemo the SEs are cumulative.  However I have found I do not ever have normal SEs.....now I am experiencing the funky nails on Adriamycin that I got with Abraxane and supposedly that does not happen with the Adriamycin so go figure....even onco said it was not a usual SE.   Everyone is so different.   When I did Halaven, I was fine Wed. afternoon,(would get it Wed. AM)  Thurs and until about 1 on Friday....then I would go to bed and sleep for a day.  I was never sure if this was the chemo itself or the steroids wearing off.  What really hit me hard while on it was the neulasta shots I would get.....those really made me feel like I had the flu....aches, elevated temp, chills.   However, taking the claritin helped....took it before injection and after and maybe it was partly mental, but it did help a lot. Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 11:45PM - edited Apr 25, 2011 11:47PM by Marybe     This is probably one of the more stupid thoughts I have had in my life, but I am honestly thinking maybe I don't want to do this treatment.  I was thinking yesterday how I am feeling good....really good....better than I have for a long time.  My back which is a chronic deal hasn't even bothered me for almost a week.  I have been going to the bathroom without the aid of laxatives or stool softeners since it has been three weeks that I have not had any sort of chemo.  And I honestly think my memory is a little better or at least my thoughts are not quite as scrambled, but maybe they are really more screwed up that usual because never before have I thought about just not doing treatment.  I know it would be suicide, but since my cancer has always been slow growing maybe I would have another year of feeling really great.....or I guess it could end up being painful.  It's one of those things I just don't know, but I hate to give up feeling good to feel like crap.  Many of you have been very helpful in sharing your SEs with me and in general you have said it is not all that bad of a treatment and is doable,  But I also read that it did not work for several of you.  I know it is always a gamble when you start a treatment as to whether or not it will work, BUT have any of you done this treatment and had it work on both your organs and bones?  Right now my bone mets are unchanged from last scan and it is the liver my onco is worried about, but I need a treatment that is going to work on both of them.  My tumor markers are really high, 2,177, and I know many of you had a dramatic drop in those, however when you had scans the tumors were still there.  I guess my problem is I want it all....I want the tumor markers to go down and I want the tumors in my liver to shrink and I want the bone to not get any worse. Asking a lot, I know.  Are there some of you who can tell me that this is a treatment that has really worked wonders for you?.....I hope so, for your sake as well as mine.  I can deal with SEs if the treatment works.  Thanks so much.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 10:23AM Marybe wrote: Jenn, This last chemo I was on Gemzar made me feel like I had the flu two days after I had the treatment....I ached all over, it hurt to sit on the toilet seat because it was cool and I was hot and it just sent jolts up when when I sat on it, and my eyes really burned.  That is always the first sign that I have an elevated temp, my eyes burn.  My normal temp is about 96.8 or 97.  We did not even have a thermometer in the house so I sent my husband out to get one and when I took my temp,  it was 99 (no big deal for a normal person, but a temp for me)  It kept going up and the highest reading was almost 102,   I just stayed in bed, took tylenol, drank lots of water and ate popcicles and in the middle of the night woke up all wet and even the sheets were wet and then my temp started going back to normal.  It lasted for a little over 24 hrs.  The onco nurse tried to blame it on the Xgeva shot, but it happened again the next time I got chemo and it was not an Xgeva week....my temp did not go as high and the achiness did not last as long and then it never happened again.  My theory is that my body adjusted to it.  Is there a possiblity you might have actually had the flu.  Maybe you picked up something if your white count was low.  I hope you are feeling better and am glad to hear they your scans are stable.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 11:21PM Marybe wrote: I got my lst treatment today....they gave me aloxi and decadron ( I think that was it, some steroid.10 mg maybe?) .....the actual treament would have only taken about 45 mins including the premeds and saline drip, BUT they always make you sit there forever.  Fortunately I know a lot of women there from always going on Wed. so we sit and visit.  My white count was 6.4 today when they ran the blood work.  I don't get a shot of neulasta until next week and then on the 3rd week when it is a non chemo week, it will be time for my Xgeva for my bones again.  The best news is that I met a woman in the treatment room who has been on halaven since Jan....she said she has tolerated it very well, her hair is actually growing back even though she is still getting treatment and the TUMORS IN HER LIVER DID NOT SHOW UP at all on her last scan.  The onco was going to reduce her dosage since she has really bad neuropathy....can't grasp things and drops things a lot, and the neuropathy in her feet has gone all the way up her leg.  She has been on several chemos before and said this is an easier one, at least for her.   I know many of you told me this and I appreciate all your input and feedback, but it really helps to actually physically see someone who is on it.  I kept asking her things....she said her nails are very brittle and she has a difficult time typing....now that could really cramp my style....if I am unable to clean teeth, I would at least hope to be able to type on the boards in my free time. But I have to keep in mind, we are all so different.  I will keep you posted and will be coming here to see how the rest of you are doing.  Got a RX for zofran filled, but don't know if I will need it or not.  I am so glad this thread is here.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 02:53AM Marybe wrote: BMAGIN, So sorry you are joining us, you are so young. I also have it in my humeral heads....both of them....actually I have it all over the place in my bones, but none below the hip.  Sacrum, sternum, ribs, spine, all over the place.  But it is the liver that has them worried. Yaiy,   I have one called a cell search done and know it is one of those....it was 1 one time, but I actually think they screwed up on reading that and it was zero because the next time they told me 0 and I said oh, it went down and the PA asked what I meant and I said the nurse told me it was one last time and she showed me the test and said no, it was zero, she was looking at the wrong thing.  Now that gives me a lot of confidence in getting my results over the phone.  But every time its been zero and I have had it done about 10 times total over the last 5 years....it's a circulating cell search, I think.  The CA27/29, the one that is sky high, 2.709, I have had done every few months ever since I was diagnosed Stage lV. Today I want for my neulasta shot and took claratin as someone advised me to  do to lessen the SEs.  So far nothing.  Also I have now had two doses of halaven as of yesterday and no SEs with it either....I am sure I would have gotten nausea by now if I was going to.  And actually I am much less constipated that I was on navelbine or gemzar.  They told me my hair will thin out, not fall out like it did before, but like I said nothing, absolutely nothing so far.  Oh, my white count did drop in half , but that is why I am getting the neulasta shot.  Next week, I am having no treatment since it is my week off, but I will be  having blood work and also getting my Xgeva shot for my bones.  Maybe this drug will be an easy one for me....I just hope it works.  More than one person told me to expect bone pain with the neulasta, but that it won't start for a few days.....sure do hope I dodge that SE.

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 03:39PM - edited Jun 12, 2011 03:44PM by Marybe Oh, I am hanging in there with you, Susan.  What else can I do?  I have completed my two cycles now and I am sure he told me we would do the CA27/29 after two....can't imagine we would do scans so soon.   And I am just praying this stuff is working.  I hate chemo in general, but what I hate even more is moving on to a new chemo because the first words out of my mouth are not is this this going to work?, is this a good chemo?,..they are What's it going to do it me?   I am always so afraid of SEs and it seems most of  the time I don't get bad one except for the Abraxane.  In spite of these muscle things (at least they don't happen all the time) and the edema if that is what is causing it, and the thinning hair( still have quite a bit) and the constipation, I am finding this to be a pretty good treatment so far as SEs go.  I was googling the drug last night and did not see anything about edema so am not glad that you have it, but glad to know it's not just me.  I never did have nice little thin ankles, but now my legs are sort of looking like telphone poles...my feet are looking sort of red also.  Yaiyai, Just went back and saw your post.  I did not have any bad SEs with Gemzar....just constipation and that isn't much to deal with all things considered...but I was only doing it with Xgeva for my bones so don't know what it is like when done in combination.  Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Marybe wrote:    I had a nice long talk with my onco today....decided to schedule a consulatation appt with him so we could discuss things since I seem to always see the PA these days and knew he was not optimistic (downright pessamistic actually) about me trying out hormonal treatments that MDAnderson recommended.  I wanted to know why he felt they would not work ( he was right on the aromasin) and why he suggested I go back to MDA, if he wasn't interested in treating me since I quit the chemo he had me on or what.  Really just wanted to find out what his thoughts are and asked that question he will never answer What is my prognosis? again.  To the last question he said, well, it's difficult to say.  Said I have been rather rare in that all the women he was treating who were Stage lV who started out when I did (98) are now gone, but that I have been fortunate in that I have responded favorably to just about every treatment I have been on.  He told me I need to keep in mind, cancer is the enemy, not chemo and that he has every reason to believe that he could get me into remission again, BUT it would mean chemo.  I asked about chemo other than the abraxane which I told him I am still getting over the SEs from.  He said well, he thought gemcitabine (sp?) would be in order, but there are SEs just different ones and it is not a harsh treatment like some of the others. I guess it is also called Gemzar.   But in the meantime we are going to give this Megace a try and that means a few months before scans. He said the only reason he suggested I go back to TX is that he thought maybe they were doing some new hormonal drug studies because all the ones they have suggested are old ones and he feels that since one failed, there is a good likelihook the others will.....but he said there is always the possibility it could work and he hopes it does and proves him wrong.  I am glad I went to MDA and have loved my time off chemo, BUT the fact is I trust this man.  Who wouldn't, considering he's been keeping me going and I have been able to work this past 12 yrs under his care. I know I do not want to do anything in the taxol family again unless that is the only option left.  So I am asking for some feedback on this other drug because I learn more from these boards that just reading about SEs.  Have any of you with liver and bone mets been on this with success?  Or failure?  And what were your SEs?  And is this a medication you just stay on until it stops working or a treatment that you get for a certain time frame?   He did agree I can cut my zometa to every other month instead of monthly without jepordizing anything.  Marybe Be you own advocate and keep on your toes. Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 10:58PM Marybe wrote: You will love that Look Good, Feel Better class.....my friend Lee did it and she got all sorts of really good cosmetic products and was so excited.  She is the reason I am writing...she is young (by my standard at least, I am 60) 47 and although she had lobular and mine was ductal and we did not have the same treatments she is always asking me questions which I try to answer.  Anyway, I was talking to her tonight and she was cracking me up.  She said she's got tons of hair, close to an inch long, but it.s SILVER.  She said her eyebrows look like bruises and then just today she looked in the mirror and has all this peach fuzz!!  I said oh yeh, that will happen and she asked for how long and I said I really couldnt remember, but do know that it went away and that places I had unwanted hair before are gone.....like I dont have to pluck my eyebrows in between any more and that whisker I had is gone as well as my little mustache hairs.  But I do remember the fuzz and thinking oh great, now I am going to have a beard.  I stopped the chemo that caused my hair to fall out last July22 so its been well over a year and some of it I just dont recall.  I do know my hair was much whiter at first and in the very beginning almost what you would call colorless. It came in straight and very soft and has stayed that way, softer than my hair used to be.  My eyebrows are back, but they are not as thick or dark as they used to be, but I recall looking in the mirror and thinking what in the heck are those bruises.  I am sure she will now want to keep her hair gray since she isnt even 50, but who knows, maybe it will get darker. Mine is salt and pepper and very silvery and I like it.  My eyelashes, now those are a problem, but I am still hoping one day they will be back to normal...they grow down like a camels instead of out and I also have a few lashes that grow inward and those have to be plucked out because they scratch my cornea.  Now that is a real PIA.  But I am doing OK, have hair and feel better than I have for a long time so want to encourage you all to hang in there.  I should be ashamed of myself, but tonight when she exclaimed And today I looked in the mirror and there's all this peach fuzz!!! I just couldnt help laughing.  She.s still got drains in which is bugging her since its been 3 wks, she is going to be starting radiation once they finish filling the expanders and she's having a fit over peach fuzz.  Ah, ain.t it grand to be a woman!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 09:25AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:52AM by Marybe   You probably feel we are being left out because we are.  It's sort of like when you run into someone and they ask How are you?,....do they really want to know?  Probably not because everyone is so wrapped up in their own problems.  Also when it comes to breast cancer those who are not Stage lV, do not want to consider the possibility that some day it could be them.  So far as those terms survivor and battle, I have never thought of my cancer in those terms although that is exactly how the onco I am with now described it to me....said we  had to look at it as a war and there were lots of weapons to use, but why jump in with the heavy duty artillary when there was a good chance we could achieve the same results using less agressive techniques.  He was referring to hormonal vs chemo at the time. So fighting and war and survivor just must be terms they use a lot when it come to this disease ......and I suppose as opposed to lying down and just letting it take over we are fighting and if we are still alive we are surviving.  But Stage lV is not something people can relate to unless they have been there.  Even though I have been extemely fortunate and am able to still work and feel I lead a pretty "normal" life, it is there in the back of my mind and when it comes time for scans, I always worry that this may be IT.  I look healthy and I keep up with my friends and I do my job at work and that is what I told my onco was important to me right from the beginning, I did not want people to look at me and think Oh my God, she's really sick, she's got cancer.  In a way this has backfired because everyone thinks I have beaten it and they will say stupid things  you have mentioned already like,  But you look great,  or You're going to be OK now, right?, You are through with  treatments now, aren't you?   They don't understand that this is something I am going to be dealing with the rest of my life. And a lot of them don't even know what Stage IV is....I myself didn't until I went to the library and read about it at the library after my diagnosis.  I am glad to hear that there have been a few stories told this month about Stage lV, but am sure that in general they want to tell the public the ones that have happy endings.  I may be overly negative here, but I honestly think it will always come back....was 8 yrs on me (probably less, but not diagnosed til then), I know a woman who was 12 years out and look at all the women on these boards , who had recurrences.  It is a determined disease and does not give up easily. I was involved with trying to get info out about Stage lV in the early days...have already told on here about how I was very involved in a letter writing campaign which never really materialized even though thousands and thousands of letter were written....the woman who started it was Stage lV and she is long gone. I just sort of got uninvolved after that, although I was in a program they they produced for the internet last year....sort of doubt if it opened any eyes though....I have not given up, but just pretty much live with my cancer and know that they are not going to come out with a cure in my lifetime.  I know Oprah won't help.....we tried to get her involved when we were doing the letter campaign....letters to the paper are a good idea and I would imagine if there was a woman editor or one in charge of articles, you would have a better chance of not being stuck on the back page or down in a corner, IF you are lucky enough to make print.  Also contacting Ellen is a good idea....she seems like a down-to-earth sort and from what I have read does reach out and help people.  What you wrote, was great English Major....also I can relate to  your feelings , Bo. Thank you for starting this topic, Cat.   I think we have to be our own advocates when it comes to this and I for one have chosen not to wear pink this month.  Today I am going to a big fundraising luncheon at the convention center, but only because my husband bought tickets....if they ask for any comments from the audience I will raise my hand and ask What about Stage lV?
