Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 04:00AM - edited Dec 17, 2011 06:07AM by Marybe Well, hello you fellow eaters.  Have you all been in the closet?.....thought I was all alone in this one.  I used to blame it on the decadron, but I really think a lot of it is stress or the combo of meds you are getting.  It used to be decadron would keep me awake for exactly 2 1/2 days after treatment....I would get my treatment on a Wed. morning and be going strong until Friday afternoon when if I would sit down I would fall asleep in a chair mid-sentence.  I would go to bed and then sleep for a day.  I ate a lot also.....would get these food cravings that I had to satisfy RIGHT NOW.....found myself pulling off exits to get whatever I had seen on a billboard or heard an add for on the radio, BUT I must admit I always have liked fast food (as well as food for the more sophisticated palates) and think there is nothing like a Burger King Whopper or Rally's fries to satisfy hunger.  I was eating things I had never eaten before in my life also just because they sounded good or they were there.  I must confess I did the same thing though when I was doing Abraxane and lost my sense of taste completely....then I was searching for something I could get a taste out of and that led to quite a food quest.  I actually loved the energy and got a lot done staying up most of the night. I would look forward to getting lots of projects down the night after treatment.  Prior to this chemo,  I had them lower my dose until I was off it all together (this was when I was really feeling sleep deprived ), but I still ate.  I think steroids are meant to help with the nausea as well as pain, but I can't swear to this. Now, I am doing decadron again , BUT it is not keeping me awake at all....nothing is keeping me awake with this one and I am sleeping more than I ever did in my life.  And  alas, I am  overeating, but I think it is because I feel I am entitled to eat whatever I want at this point in life.  I know I will be unhappy later when I am observing yet another chin in the mirror, but it tastes so good going down.  I told one of my friends once, that I actually enjoy being stuffed.   And so the cycle goes on.  I am sure it does increase our appetites, but in my case I think it is also partly mental....I am rewarding myself with food for doing treatment.  I am not saying that is what you all are doing because I know for a fact I was starving that one time I was doing decadron, but I also found it could be controlled.   I did WW and would then pig out on healthy food so it is possible to lose while on it, but unless it really bothers you putting on the lbs, I would not worry about it.....at least not until the holidays are over and you have had your fill of Xmas cookies, Yule logs, egg nog and fudge.   I used to have no problem turning down sweets, now I love them.  Carbs always have been my downfall......I would order a grilled cheese with mac and cheese and a baked potato on this side  if I didn't think people would stop by my table and stare. So what am I doing up now if the decadron isn't doing it?.....I went to bed really early and for some reason my body now feels like it is morning, but I am going back to bed just as soon as I let the dogs out.  Oddly enough, I am not hungry so I think I will just go get some more ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZs.   You are not alone, Kathy.   This is a great thread you started.   Oh, I forgot to add whenever I am going for a scan (unless it is one where I cannot eat beforehand) or waiting for results, I really shovel it in. It took me a long time to realize that I stress eat, but I do for sure.......used to chain smoke when I was stressed, but thank goodness I quit that one a long time ago

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 09:05PM - edited Jun 20, 2011 09:07PM by Marybe   I finished the two cycles the onco wanted to do of the halaven before doing any tests....two weeks on, one week off is a cycle.  Last week was the start of the 3rd cycle so we did the CA27.29 and although I was disappointed that my tumor markers are still very high 2,635, at least they have gone down from the 2,709 when we started this treatment.  Next week I will be getting neulasta on Thurs.  after my treatment on Wed.  Isn't it amazing how the claritin works!?!...I had my doubts when they told me about it, but last night I did not have one single ache or pain.  My hair loss is at a standstill and I am still going without a wig and actually got a compliment on my haircut today from someone I don't know and who doesn't know my hair used to be thick.  I replied with You are kidding me, aren't you?  This was a friend of a friend so the friend then explained to her that I am doing chemo.  My onco will not form any opinion on blood work alone and they have me scheduled for scans July 20.  This weekend I was so tired I did not want to drive anywhere so dear old Dad had to drive to me...risky at his age, but he does it all the time and I could just not even think of getting in the car, let alone driving.  Most of the time I am fine, but when the tiredness sets it, it just sort of takes over.  I think the vitamins I am taking are keeping the neuropathy stable.

celexa....I went to talk to someone because I was feeling overwhlemed and just did not feel like was coping with things well, could not concentrate and get things done like paying bills....so we tired one and then the other, but I found that while on them they really made me feel like I didn't care about anything...things were not upsetting me, but I also found I was not laughing at things that should have been funny and did not like that feeling of "not feeling"....but maybe that was just my reaction.  And on this chemo I am not feeling depressed or overwhelmed and am actually hopeful that it will work since I again sat today in the treatment room with a woman who had been on it since Jan with excellent results and only real SE is neuropathy and her hair is actually growing back while she is still on the chemo.  I think that many of you doing the AC followed with Taxol or taxotere will find you hair starting to come back while still on the treatments.  MamaV.....your boss had better watch it....I am sure there is some sort of rule that you cannot be discriminated against in the workplace for cancer....had a booklet somewhere that I will look for called your rights as a cancer patient in the workplace.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 07:15PM Marybe wrote: Oddly enough it is somehow comforting to get started, even if it is not something you want to do.  No, it's not to early to feel SEs....lst day I think is, but I know when I was doing Abraxane, which my onco says is the same at taxol, I felt it two, two and 1/2 days later.....would get it on Wed. and be raring to go on Wed afternoon and did not sleep much at all that night, on Thurs would still have lots of energy, then on Friday afternoon I wear just totally give out....would sit down in a chair and my head would just drop off and I would wake up with drool on my shirt....then it got to the point where I would just about crawl in the door on Friday afternoon and go right to bed.  I think just about all chemo is cumulative and you have to be on it for awhile for the SEs to show up, except for nausea and fatigue and those can happen early on..  The fact that with most ACT treatments , it's over in about 6 months and even though you don't think it now, the time will go pretty fast.  How do you feel weird?   I cannot say I am really hungry, but for sure I am having pizza tonight....another one of those little food rewards I am so fond of.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 08:19AM Marybe wrote: mebmarj,  I am confused on what you wrote re the neulasta and two shots?  I am supposed to get one of these shots every two weeks, on the Thurs after my chemo treatment on Wed.  IF my white count is too low inbetween those times, I will get it before then.  I would rank the pain I had with it a severe...hit me like a ton of rocks.  I thought it was over yesterday since I was only hurting in a few places, but I am still getting these little jolts of pain here and there.  I talked to one of my friends who got procreit (sp) shots and she said they really caused her the same SEs that I had with the neulasta.  I see the onco on Wed. for bloodwork and my Xgeva (for my bones) and am going to ask him exactly what his recommendations are for preventing SEs since they did not tell me anything last time and I was fortunate enough to be on the board and learned about the claritin (too late, but now I know) Steff66, Did you have a BMX or just the one side?  I hate to scare you, but in most cases I know of (two of them local friends) they do both since with lobular it is very likely to show up in the exact same place in the other breast....read about lobular and it talks about the mirror image.   I think chemo is a good idea as a follow up regardless of size also.....mine was not even a cm yet, I was not yet Stage l, and no nodes were involved and I did not have chemo or tamox and it came back and was discovered 8 yrs later....knowing what I know today, at the very least I would tell them I wanted to do tamoxifen since you are ER+.  I am not saying any of this to worry you, but you did ask for every comment.

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 06:48PM Marybe wrote:    Oh, I am so sorry to hear this.  It is always a blow when you think you are doing OK, to find out you have mets,  However, I will tell you this and you may think it sounds stupid and that there is nothing good about this at all, BUT if you have to have mets, the sternum is not a bad place for it to be.  When my BC was first discovered to have recurred, it was in my sternum, liver and lung and the place that was the most extensive was my sternum.  I think if the onco I had at the time had been on the ball and listened to my complaints about this pain I had right in the middle of my chest (my sternum) for several years, it would have stayed there.  And as the onco I have now told me when I switched to him, if you have to have it in the bone, the sternum is not a bad place to have it because it's not as if you are going to fall down and break it as  you might a  hip or a wrist or some other area.  So even though I know having mets is not what you wanted to hear, it could have  been a lot worse.  Once a treatment plan is decided upon and you get rid of pain you have been having, you will be surprised at how easy it is to get back to a relatively normal life....not knowing is the worst, at least for me. Once you know, you can do something about it.  I don't know what your onco is going to suggest, but AIs can be used for bone mets.   You would not have wanted an alien....The National Enquirer would have been hounding you day and night.
